channel.title: Home on the way we R
channel.description: Recent content in Home on the way we R

item.title: Making of the website: A tribute
item.description: The first person who must be thanked is Yihui Xie. Without him, none of this would have been possible. I don’t know how many times I had taken a peek at Yihui’s website while making this one. That blog is an inspiring one I must say. This is based on a theme by Yihui, Hugo Ivy I started making the website with practically zero knowledge of CSS, HTML or anything related to websites.

item.title: The plot of life: a ggplot
item.description: A ggplot2 implementation of the ‘Timeline of Thanks’ plot from the book ‘Storytelling with data’.

item.title: Another Note on A blogdown Tutorial
item.description: This is a summary. Which is to be know to me. Not by you. By me and only my.

item.title: A Quick Note on Two Beautiful Websites
item.description: To me, the two most impressive websites based on blogdown are: Rob J Hyndman’s personal website. Live Free or Dichotomize by Lucy and Nick et al. I’m sure there will be more.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This sample post is mainly for blogdown users. If you do not use blogdown, you can skip the first section. 1. Markdown or R Markdown This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: 1. You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```` ```{r} ````); 2.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. Inline code You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.

item.title: About
item.description: This is about me Masters dropout

item.title: Zauad Shahreer Abeer
item.description: People usually add their degrees after their name. It’s a way to show their achievements. I believe dropping out is one too. The master has failed more times than the beginner has even tried. – Stephen McCranie Programming has always intrigued me. Owing to mediocre results in the admission exam, I did not have the option to choose CSE as a major. A teacher of mine advised me to take Statistics.
